There are several theories to explain the coronal heating problem. Recent observations from space-based observatories like the Parker Solar Probe and Solar Orbiter are providing crucial data.

articles.title: Study reveals humans move 40 times more than all wild animals combined
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Human movement has increased by 4,000 percent since the Industrial Revolution 170 years ago. Movement of marine animals has dropped by about 60 percent. Since 1850, the combined weight of wild land and marine mammals has dropped from 200 million tonnes to 60 million tonnes. People and their livestock now make up about 1.1 billion tonnes.

articles.title: When Institutional ‘Science' Runs Counter to Human Reason
articles.author: Jeffrey A. Tucker
articles.summary: last week, a scientific journal came out with an article that made national news briefly and then vanished. It claimed that our habit of eating beef instead of chicken was responsible for warming the planet. The innovation in the study was to overlay beef eating with geography so that you could tell how much beef eating in your zip code was ruining the climate.

articles.title: Magnitude 6.1 Earthquake Hits Turkiye, Buildings Collapse

articles.title: Slow but savage: Why hurricanes like Melissa are becoming more common

articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has become a Category 5 cyclone. It's fueled by abnormally warm Caribbean waters. Scientists say rapid intensification and stalling storms are on the rise in a warming climate. It could amplify its impacts through relentless rain, storm surge and wind.

articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: The Caribbean Community (CARICOM) expresses deep concern for Jamaica, Haiti, The Bahamas, the Cayman Islands, and the Turks and Caicos Islands, which are in the path of Hurricane Melissa. articles.title: HEADLINE: 'New Study Finds Recent Global Warming Mostly Driven By Natural Forces—Not CO2', by Pierre Gosselin
articles.author: Pierre Gosselin
articles.summary: New study finds that recent global warming is mostly due to natural climate factors, with only one-third linked to rising greenhouse gases. The study questions the alarmist claims about 'heat in the pipeline' and suggests that future warming will be driven by natural forcings.

articles.title: Conquering the Arctic: How China and Russia are joining forces

articles.summary: As the Arctic ice melts, a new Cold War is heating up. Russia and China are rewriting the rules of global power. A container ship has just blazed through the Arctic route from China to Europe in record time. articles.author: Pierre Gosselin
articles.summary: Ad Huijser's paper challenges the widely held assumption that rising greenhouse gas (GHG) concentrations are the sole or even the primary drivers of recent global warming. Two-thirds of the observed global warming must be attributed to natural factors. This increase in incoming solar energy is likely due to natural changes in factors like cloud cover and surface albedo.

articles.title: Mozambique Receives $2 Million Insurance Premium for Drought Protection As African Risk Financing Programme Reaches $150 Million Milestone
articles.summary: Mozambique received a $2 million insurance premium for drought protection covering the 2025-2026 agricultural season. It is the third consecutive year of coverage under the African Development Bank's disaster risk financing programme. The forum was held from October 14 to 16 under the theme "Building Africa's Resilience through Transformative Climate and Disaster Risk Financing and Insurance".

articles.title: Spain Endures Hottest Summer On Record In 2025
articles.summary: Spain had its hottest summer since records began more than six decades ago. The average temperature between June 1 and August 31, 2025, reached 24.2 degrees Celsius (75.5 degrees Fahrenheit), surpassing the previous record of 24.1 C set only last year. The last Spanish summer without a heatwave was back in 2014. Europe is warming at twice the global average rate since the 1980s. Mediterranean region is heating up 20% faster than the rest of the world. The combination of extreme temperatures and low rainfall created ideal conditions for wildfires to ignite and spread.

articles.title: Coming soon: Australia to hit population of 28 million within a year driven by mass ‘artificial' migration surge
articles.author: Jordan Knight
articles.summary: Australia's population is growing rapidly. The population growth rate is driven almost entirely by immigration. Demographers warn the population growth is putting pressure on hospitals, schools, and housing. 71% of Australians want a temporary pause on immigration to let housing, roads, and hospitals catch up.

articles.title: At 12, I saw Australia burn: Now I'll fly over it with Sussan Ley

articles.summary: Doctors for the Environment Australia (DEA) released a report on the effects of climate change on mental health. The report cited the problem of eco-anxiety or eco-distress, which it defined as the "chronic fear of environmental doom". It said a rapid transition away from fossil fuels and restoration of nature is needed. Doctors will meet federal politicians on Tuesday to highlight their concerns.

articles.title: Global majority's fight for achieving economic justice
articles.author: Project Syndicate
articles.summary: The world is experiencing a series of political, ecological, social, and economic ruptures. According to the Indicators of Global Climate Change report, we are only three years away from breaching the 1.5C global warming limit set in the 2015 Paris climate agreement. There is insufficient climate finance from wealthy countries and an unfair debt system that traps low-income countries in a perpetual cycle of distress. Civil-society groups and NGOs from across the Global South will meet with their Global North allies at the People's Summit for Global Economic Justice on the sidelines of the upcoming G20 Leaders' Summit in Johannesburg. The attendees will work together to map structural alternatives to the 'societies of enm

articles.title: Human Movement Over 40 Times Greater Than That Of All Wild Land Animals Combined
articles.author: IFL Science

articles.title: Human Movement Around Earth Over 40 Times Greater Than That Of All Wild Land Animals Combined
articles.author: Stephen Luntz
articles.summary: Humans make up a third of the world's animal biomass. Wild land animals make up 5% of the biomass, while humans make up 4% of all land and air animals. With the aid of planes, trains, and automobiles, humans travel a lot further than most animals each year.

articles.summary: Rising temperatures are chipping away at sleep and health, too, because of the lack of air circulation in the last few months. It's affecting people's sleep and their health too. It is also affecting their physical and mental health. It makes them sleep less and their physical health worse.

articles.title: Red-listed skylark pictured at Roydon Common near Gaywood
articles.author: Shaun Webbley
articles.summary: Nick Bowman was taking pictures at Roydon Common near Gaywood earlier this month when he captured the rare sight of a skylark. Skylark is a small brown bird, larger than a sparrow but smaller than a starling. Its population numbers have fallen dramatically since the 1970s and it is harder to spot the winged creatures.

articles.title: New Research Upends Theory that Indigenous Australians Hunted Large Animals to Extinction

articles.summary: Analysis of two 50,000-year-old fossils from Australia suggests that First Peoples valued big animals for their fossils as well as for their meat, collecting bones and transporting them over great distances. For decades, scientists viewed cut marks on the fossils as signs that Indigenous Australians hunted large prey.

articles.title: Heatwaves threaten to dry up supply of ‘hairy crabs'

articles.title: The Arctic is the world's fastest-warming region

articles.summary: The Arctic and Antarctic are geographic opposites. Antarctica is a continent surrounded by water, whereas the Arctic is a water body surrounded by land. The Arctic is colder than the Antarctic.    i.e. there is no ice in the Arctic, only water.

articles.title: Spain's hottest areas see property prices cool as temperatures rise
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are affecting property values in Spain. Each additional day above 35°C leads to a 0.08% decrease in sales prices and 0.15% decreases in rents. In cooler regions the increase accelerates twice as much. Buyers are moving to more temperate provinces. CaixaBank report confirms that home sales are increasing most strongly in "fresh Spain".

articles.title: ‘Still fighting for basic rights': Climate distress isn't an electoral issue in poll-bound Bihar
articles.author: Srish Prakash
articles.summary: Bihar is one of India's most climate-vulnerable states. The state is going to hold its two-phased assembly election on November 6 and 11. Political debates focus on caste, crime, corruption, and leadership. The Council on Energy, Environment and Water ranked Bihar as the fifth most vulnerable state in its report that mapped India's climate vulnerability.

articles.title: Unseasonal Rains Surge Through Gujarat: A Weather Anomaly Raises Concerns
articles.author: Ahmedabad
articles.summary: Unseasonal rains swept across Gujarat on Monday, spurred by a depression in the Arabian Sea. Rajula taluka in Amreli recorded 175 mm of rainfall. The deluge poses significant risks to agriculture, especially groundnuts, cotton, and paddy nearing harvest.

articles.title: Revealed: What the world will look like in 2100
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: FutureGuessr is an online game showing the damage climate change will do to the world in 75 years' time. It's free and presents the world as it will be in that time in a 75-year-old version of the game. It was previously described as the greatest threat to our existence.

articles.title: Revealed: What the world will look like in 2100 - so, can you guess where each location is?
articles.author: JONATHAN CHADWICK
articles.summary: FutureGuessr is an online game that shows the damage climate change will do to the world in 75 years' time. It presents hundreds of AI-generated locations as they're expected to look in 2100. The game is aimed at building support for climate action.

articles.title: NGOs note 28 new ‘carbon bomb' projects since 2021
articles.author: Al Jazeera
articles.summary: Twenty-eight new 'carbon bomb' projects have been launched across the globe over the past five years. Major global banks are exacerbating climate change and future emissions by giving carte blanche to fossil fuel companies that are destroying the planet, according to NGOs.

articles.title: Jamaica braces for a possible category 5 Hurricane Melissa; Dominica moves to ensure safety of students in Jamaica and Cuba
articles.summary: Melissa has been upgraded to a Category 5 hurricane. The storm is expected to hit Jamaica within hours. The government has ordered evacuations in parts of the capital, Kingston, and other vulnerable communities. All 881 emergency shelters across the island are now open. Up to 40 inches of rain is possible in some areas of Jamaica over the next four days.

articles.title: Climate Scaring: Coral Tipping Point or Media Mirage?
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: The earth has reached its first catastrophic tipping point linked to greenhouse gas emissions. Warm water coral reefs are facing a long-term decline due to the warming climate.    The Guardian put it that the earth has "reached its first catastropical tipping point".

articles.title: The Vast Geothermal Processes Heating Greenland's Ice Sheets
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: Intense geothermal heat is behind Greenland's vast network of hidden rivers and lakes beneath its ice.    .   in Greenland's network ofHidden Rivers and Lakes beneath its Ice. in Greenland. in the United States. in other places. in Europe.

articles.title: 10,000 key buildings including schools, nursing homes and hospitals are in danger from severe floods in Spain - Olive Press News Spain
articles.author: Alex Trelinski
articles.summary: There are 10,197 infrastructures in Spain that could be affected by severe floods with a recurrence period of 500 years. The study details, quantifies and classifies facilities, services and buildings located in flood-prone areas of Spain based on official data. The highest risk category includes 420 nursing homes, 1,126 schools, 114 Policia Nacional stations, 116 Guardia Civil barracks, 112 hospitals and 82 radioactive facilities. 37% are in Catalunya followed by 16% in Galicia.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa forces Dominican Republic growers to watch for floods and strong winds
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is making its way through the Caribbean Sea. Farmers in the Dominican Republic are taking preventative measures to protect crops. Rosanna Nin Cid of GL.Sila Export SRL is concerned about the potential impact on agricultural infrastructure, irrigation systems and greenhouses. Dundee Citrus Growers is keeping a close eye on the storm.

articles.title: The Southern Ocean is building up a colossal 'burp' that could reignite global warming, scientists ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: The Southern Ocean has acted as a major buffer against global warming for around 200 years. But the ocean around Antarctica is building and it's not helping the fight against climate change anymore.    .      for more information visit: http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/30/climate-change/

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa puts lives of 1.6 million children at risk — UNICEF
articles.author: TASS
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has intensified to Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson scale. It is moving westward with the speed of 6 kmph, bringing winds that reach 72 m/s. Evacuations were reported in Jamaica, including its capital, and in eastern regions of Cuba.

articles.title: Unusual Chinese delicacy under threat due to heatwave conditions
articles.author: Brenda Goh
articles.summary: Chinese hairy crab farmers have experienced their most challenging period in the last three years due to extreme weather. High temperatures and extended summers since 2022 have disrupted the crabs' breeding cycles and growth, leading to significant losses. Farmers express concern about the long-term viability of the industry if crabs cannot adapt to climate change.

articles.title: Greenhouse Gases' Heat Trapping Ability Hasn't Saturated As Some Predicted – But Why?
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: There are a lot of claims about global warming and climate change being disproved online. Most of them have been debunked by scientific papers and popular science websites like IFLScience and IFLJournal have already debunked the claims.    ifljournal.com has already debunked it.

articles.title: Greenhouse Gases' Heat Trapping Ability Hasn't Saturated As Some Predicted – But Why?
articles.author: Stephen Luntz
articles.summary: There are many claims to disprove global warming and climate change. One of them is that greenhouse gases do warm the planet up to a certain point. It took scientists decades to spot the flaw in the argument. Knut Ångström, a rival of Svante Arrhenius, wanted to prove his enemy wrong.

articles.title: GEM, cities of Miramar and Lauderhill to send food and supplies to Jamaica amid Melissa relief efforts
articles.author: Dannielle Garcia
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is barreling toward Jamaica. It has already claimed at least three lives in Haiti and one in the Dominican Republic. South Florida cities and organizations are getting ready to send support in the form of much-needed food and other necessities. Global Empowerment Mission's headquarters in Doral is filling boxes with necessities.

articles.title: GEM preparing to send food and supplies to Jamaica amid relief efforts as Hurricane Melissa approaches
articles.author: Dannielle Garcia
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is barreling toward Jamaica. It has already claimed at least three lives in Haiti and one in the Dominican Republic. South Floridians are getting ready to send support in the form of food and other necessities. At the Global Empowerment Mission's headquarters in Doral, volunteers spent much of the weekend filling boxes with necessities.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa reaches category 5 with 260 km/h winds forcing evacuations in Jamaica
articles.author: Redação
articles.summary: Melissa is a category 5 hurricane with 260 km/h winds. It's expected to make landfall in Jamaica on Tuesday and move on to Cuba and the Bahamas by Wednesday. Four deaths have already occurred due to storms associated with Melissa, three in Haiti and one in the Dominican Republic.

articles.title: Dominican Republic returns to normal as Abinader lifts Hurricane Melissa restrictions
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: President Luis Abinader announced the lifting of preventive measures across most of the Dominican Republic after Hurricane Melissa moved away from the country. Only four provinces remain under red alert: Barahona, Pedernales, Bahoruco, and Independencia. Electricity generation has remained stable at 98% and drinking water services are being restored. Preliminary damage reports show 735 homes affected and 3,765 people displaced.

articles.title: The Southern Ocean is building up a colossal 'burp' that could reignite global warming, scientists warn
articles.author: XANTHA LEATHAM
articles.summary: The Southern Ocean around Antarctica is building up a 'burp' that could trigger an increase in global temperatures. The effects could last for more than a century and affect some of the world's most vulnerable countries. Global warming will peak at around 2.25°C above pre–industrial levels and then drop to below 1.5°C by the year 2600.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa: only 4 provinces on red alert
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is now classified as an intense hurricane with winds of 220 km/h. Four provinces are on red alert, twelve on yellow alert, and thirteen on green alert. Boats operating along the Caribbean coast are advised to stay in port due to strong winds and dangerous waves.

articles.title: MP Alex Brewer meets environmentalists for round-table event
articles.author: Jasmine Kelly
articles.summary: The round-table climate change event was held in St John's Church, Hartley Wintney, on October 18. Environmentalists met with North East Hampshire MP Alex Brewer as part of a mass lobby for stronger climate leadership in Parliament. The gathering was attended by representatives from Greener Basingstoke, WWF, Greenpeace, Friends of the Earth, and CPRE.

articles.title: Himachal lost Rs 46,000 crore to natural disasters in five years: Human Development Report 2025
articles.author: Saurabh Parashar
articles.summary: Himachal Pradesh has suffered an estimated loss of Rs 46,000 crore owing to natural disasters over the past five years. The report was released on Sunday by Chief Minister Sukhvinder Singh Sukhu. It highlights the growing impact of climate change on Himachal's economy, public health, and ecology.

articles.title: Zimbabwe Activates Disaster Plans As Cyclone Season Looms ⋆ Pindula News
articles.author: Lovemore
articles.summary: Civil Protection Unit (CPU) director Nathan Nkomo said the department has activated its disaster management systems from national to local levels as the 2025/26 rainy season begins. Several cyclones are expected to hit SADC countries. Every year, the government puts together a contingency plan to tackle weather-related hazards.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa threatens catastrophic flooding in Jamaica and Haiti
articles.author: Peter Kristof
articles.summary: Melissa is a Category 4 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 233 km/h. It is expected to make landfall in Jamaica on Monday evening or Tuesday morning. The storm is forecast to become a Category 5 hurricane. Four people were killed by Melissa in Haiti and in the Dominican Republic over the weekend.

articles.title: Erratic Melissa!
articles.summary: Flooding and storm surges are a threat as Hurricane Maria bears down on Jamaica. The storm is expected to make landfall in Jamaica on Sunday.       in the early morning hours of Sunday, September 11th. It is a Category 4 hurricane.

articles.title: Classes suspended from Guantánamo to Camagüey due to "imminent impact of Hurricane Melissa."
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: The Ministry of Education of Cuba announced the suspension of classes from Guantánamo to Camagüey due to the hurricane Melissa. The Cuban government confirmed the evacuation of around 650,000 people in the most threatened provinces. Trains, buses, flights, and maritime transport are cancelled in the eastern part of the country.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa now rare Category 5 storm as it closes in on Jamaica
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: Melissa has damaged 750 homes and displaced more than 3,760 people across the region, killing at least three people in Haiti and one in the Dominican Republic. Forecasts call for extreme rainfall and a high storm surge on Jamaica's southern coast, with eastern Jamaica receiving 40 inches of rain and a 13 feet storm surge.

articles.title: Category 5 Hurricane Melissa Targets Jamaica Ahead of Tuesday Landfall
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: Melissa has intensified into a Category 4 hurricane with winds of 140 mph and is threatening Jamaica and Haiti with catastrophic flooding. The storm has caused at least three fatalities in Haiti and at least four fatalities in the Dominican Republic. Cuba is under hurricane warnings and officials are evacuating and activating shelters.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa Jamaica Updates: Tourism Shutdowns and Economic Fallout Loom as Category 4 Storm Nears Landfall
articles.author: Marie Joy Toledo
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has strengthened into a Category 4 storm in the Caribbean Sea. It is moving slowly westward at 5 mph and is expected to make landfall on the southern coast of Jamaica late on Monday or early Tuesday. Norman Manley International Airport near Kingston and Sangster International Airport in Montego Bay were closed on Sunday. Dozens of inbound and outbound flights were cancelled. Cruise lines suspended calls to Jamaican ports, and several coastal resorts temporarily shut down operations.

articles.title: Letter: Spend funds on climate mitigation, not stadium
articles.summary: On Oahu, we use more than 150 million gallons of groundwater per day. We need desalination plants and we need to have the sand returned to the beaches regularly to prevent erosion. The Honolulu Star-Advertiser welcomes all opinions and welcomes letters to the editor.

articles.title: Climate-smart classrooms: Building Jamaica's educational resilience
articles.author: Leroy Fearon Jr
articles.summary: Jamaica's education system is facing unprecedented challenges due to climate-related disasters. Hurricane Beryl damaged over 300 schools across the island, with the repair bill exceeding $2.7 billion. The Ministry of Education, Skills, Youth and Information is uniquely positioned to lead the effort to create climate-smart classrooms.

articles.title: Alligator Pond residents urged to evacuate
articles.author: Kasey Williams
articles.summary: Alligator Pond, Jamaica's south coast, is bracing itself for Hurricane Melissa. The fishing village was hit by Hurricane Beryl last year. Evrol Christian, owner of Little Ochie Seafood Restaurant, and Councillor Omar Robinson (People's National Party, Alligator Pond Division) urge residents to evacuate the area.

articles.title: Category 4 Hurricane Melissa threatens catastrophic flooding in Jamaica and Haiti
articles.author: MAURICIO SAVARESE
articles.summary: Melissa is a Category 4 hurricane that is threatening to cause catastrophic flooding in the northern Caribbean. Melissa is expected to move near or over Jamaica early Tuesday, then cross Cuba into the southeastern Bahamas through Wednesday.      Â  “

articles.title: The ‘hairy crab' is a popular Chinese delicacy. But now it is under threat
articles.author: Brenda Goh
articles.summary: Xie Dandan's family has spent over a decade cultivating China's highly prized "hairy crab" at Yangcheng lake in the eastern province of Jiangsu. The past three years have marked the most challenging period for Xie and her family. Unusually high temperatures and longer-than-expected summers have disrupted breeding cycles since 2022.

articles.title: China's heatwaves threaten to dry up supply of yummy hairy crabs
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: The last three years have been the toughest for Xie Dandan and her family cultivating one of China's most esteemed culinary delicacies, the 'hairy crab', named for its furry claws. Unusually high temperatures and longer-than-expected summers have disrupted breeding cycles since 2022. The Chinese mitten crabs can sell for hundreds of dollars when exported.

articles.title: Research: Managed Grazing Boosts Soil Carbon in Pastures
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: A new research paper released by NSW Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development (NSW DPIRD) shows that managed grazing practices incrementally increased soil organic carbon (SOC) compared to continuous grazing in temperate pasture systems. Land use change and seasonal conditions had far greater effects than grazing management.

articles.title: 11 Birds to Recognize in the Yard This Fall
articles.author: Aqsa Salam
articles.summary: It's migration season for some birds. American Robin's behavior changes dramatically in fall. Northern Cardinal add a pop of red to autumn's muted tones. Black-capped Chickadees bring energy to feeders as fall sets in. Blue Jays bury acorns for winter and act as an alarm system for predators.

articles.title: Tracking Hurricane Melissa: Will the Category 5 storm hit NY, NJ?
articles.author: Erin Pflaumer
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is expected to hit Jamaica on Monday with heavy rain and gusty winds. Haiti and the Dominican Republic have already seen devastating flooding, with officials reporting at least four deaths. Storm surges could reach around 13 feet high near Jamaica's southern coast. In New York, the Jamaican Consulate and other outreach agencies are planning relief efforts.

articles.title: Glaciers Are Losing Their Hidden Cooling Power as Global Warming Accelerates
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: Glaciers are losing their ability to cool the air. A new study warns of a tipping point in the next decade, leading to faster melting. The next decade will be crucial for the future of the world's glaciers and for the stability of the climate they help protect.

articles.title: China's heatwaves threaten to dry up supply of delicious ‘hairy crabs'
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: Temperatures are higher than usual, which is bad for crabs. It slows their growth and stops their development.       for the crabs.  for other organisms.  For more information, go to: http://www.carcains.org/

articles.title: China's hairy crab farmers struggle as heatwaves disrupt Yangcheng lake harvest
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: The last three years have been the toughest for Xie Dandan and her family cultivating one of China's most esteemed culinary delicacies, the "hairy crab", named for its furry claws. Longer-than-expected summers and high temperatures have disrupted breeding cycles since 2022. The Chinese mitten crabs can sell for hundreds of dollars when exported.

articles.title: Cranberry Farmers Consider Turning Bogs into Wetlands in Massachusetts As Temperatures Rise
articles.author: Nicole Williams
articles.summary: Cranberry farmers in Massachusetts are struggling with rising temperatures in the Northeast. The industry generates $1.7 billion in annual revenue and employs over 6,400 people. So far, 500 acres have been restored as wetlands through nine projects and 14 more are in progress.

articles.title: Trend of ‘migratory bird' lifestyle highlights retirees' rising role in China's consumption
articles.author: People Daily
articles.summary: As temperatures drop across northern China, many seniors are once again embarking on their annual "migratory bird" journey southward. The travel peak for these seniors began in mid-September and is expected to last until mid-November.

articles.title: China's hairy crab farmers struggle to survive rising heat and erratic summers
articles.summary: Rising temperatures and erratic weather patterns are threatening China's prized hairy crab industry. The past three years have been the hardest in the 10-year journey of Xie Dandan and her family who have cultivated one of China's most valued delicacies. The Chinese mitten crabs can fetch hundreds of dollars abroad, particularly in Singapore and Japan.

articles.title: Battling the Heat: The Struggle of China's Hairy Crab Farmers
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Xie Dandan and her family have spent over a decade cultivating the highly prized 'hairy crab' in China. The past three years have been particularly challenging for them due to increased water temperatures, reduced oxygen, and thriving bacteria. Suggestions include selectively breeding heat-tolerant crabs.

articles.title: China's heatwaves threaten to dry up supply of 'hairy crabs'
articles.author: CNA
articles.summary: The last three years have been the toughest for Xie Dandan and her family cultivating one of China's most esteemed culinary delicacies, the "hairy crab". Longer-than-expected summers and high temperatures have disrupted breeding cycles since 2022. The Chinese mitten crabs can sell for hundreds of dollars when exported.

articles.title: Cyclone Montha Threatens Heavy Downpours Across West Bengal
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Cyclone Montha is expected to hit land near Kakinada in Andhra Pradesh by Tuesday night. West Bengal is bracing for significant rainfall. There is a warning of potential landslides in the hilly districts of Darjeeling and Kalimpong, alongside waterlogging threats in the plains.

articles.title: Climate change puts immense pressure on local food systems
articles.author: Guest Contributor
articles.summary: Namibia's ability to feed its people is under 'immense pressure' from climate change, the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries, Water, and Land Reform, Inge Zaamwani, warned on Saturday. World Food Day activities focus on promoting global awareness and action for the elimination of hunger, food insecurity and malnutrition.

articles.title: Extinction rate among plant and animal species has surprisingly slowed down
articles.summary: Kristen Saban and John Wiens from the University of Arizona analysed nearly 2 million species over the past 500 years and found that extinctions among plants, arthropods, and land vertebrates were highest around 100 years ago. Extinctions driving earlier forecasts were mainly caused by invasive species on isolated islands, while continental extinctions were linked to habitat destruction.

articles.title: Latin America's Poverty Falls to Record Low, but Inequality Threatens the Gains
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: The World Bank's Poverty and Equity Global Practice has released its Regional Poverty and Inequality Update for Latin America and the Caribbean (October 2025). The report portrays a region where poverty is projected to fall to 25.2 percent in 2025 and the middle class reaches a historic 42.8 percent of the population. 32 percent of Latin Americans remain vulnerable to falling back into poverty, with the Caribbean facing even higher risk at 36%. The region's economy is showing moderate but uneven growth.

articles.title: Animation Highlights First Nations' Climate Leadership
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Dept of Climate Change, Energy, Environment & Water shares a new animation that shows how First Nations knowledge helps care for Country amid climate change. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have cared for Country for over 65,000 years. Their work keeps ecosystems healthy and supports a fair, sustainable future.

articles.title: Smoke blankets scorching city as thousands still without power after storm
articles.author: William Davis
articles.summary: It was the hottest October day in 21 years, peaking at 38.7 degrees in the early afternoon. More than 50 fires were burning around the state, with the Brisbane CBD and surrounding suburbs clouded by smoke. Smoke from blazes in the Lockyer Valley and areas around Ipswich were blowing towards the coast.

articles.title: China's heatwaves threaten to dry up supply of delicious 'hairy crabs'
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: The weather has been getting worse since 2022. More heat, longer summers inhibit crabs' growth. China's heatwaves threaten to dry up supply of delicious 'hairy crabs'    Brenda Goh and Nicoco report on the situation.

articles.title: Climate Change And Why We Need To Wake Up Now!
articles.summary: Climate change is no longer a looming threat, it's the reality we're experiencing today. Every year we wait to act, we make the problem more difficult to solve. It's not about 'saving the Earth' - it's about saving ourselves, our communities, and the one home we have.

articles.title: Mozambique gets $2m AfDB drought insurance boost
articles.author: APA-Maputo
articles.summary: Mozambique has received a $2 million insurance premium for drought protection through the African Development Bank's Africa Disaster Risk Financing Programme. It is the third consecutive year of climate risk coverage for the 2025–2026 agricultural season. The AfDB subsidises premiums for participating countries and the African Risk Capacity Group delivers insurance and rapid payouts when disaster thresholds are met.

articles.title: Struggling to Survive: China's 'Hairy Crab' Farmers Battle Unpredictable Climate
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Xie Dandan and her fellow farmers in China's Yangcheng Lake are struggling with climate change. Rising temperatures and extended summers since 2022 have posed challenges for them. Breeding cycles have been disrupted, with higher temperatures slowing growth and increasing bacterial threats. The industry's future remains uncertain.

articles.title: #EyeOnMelissa: Mandatory evacuations for seven communities as Melissa nears Jamaica
articles.summary: The Government of Jamaica has ordered mandatory evacuations for seven flood-prone communities across the island as Hurricane Melissa tracks toward the country. The communities are Port Royal in Kingston, Portland Cottage and Rocky Point in Clarendon, Old Harbour Bay in St Catherine, Taylor Land, New Haven, and Riverton City in St Andrew. The order takes effect immediately.

articles.title: 1.6M Children at Risk as Hurricane Melissa Strikes
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is moving slowly across the Caribbean Sea. At least 1.6 million children are at risk. UNICEF is supporting emergency preparedness efforts in the region.  In 2025, UNICEf requested $19 million to prepare for emergencies in Latin America and the Caribbean.

articles.title: Managed grazing is best for building soil organic carbon
articles.author: Sheep Central
articles.summary: Managed livestock grazing can incrementally increase soil organic carbon. Land use change and seasonal conditions had far greater effects. High stocking rates did not influence soil carbon compared to low stocking rates. Bare ground was one of the strongest predictors of SOC change, with more bare ground associated with lower SOC stocks.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa roars toward Jamaica as a Category 4 storm as island...
articles.author: Dánica Coto
articles.summary: Melissa could become the first Category 4 hurricane to make landfall in Jamaica in recent history. The storm has already damaged more than 750 homes across the country and displaced more than 3,760 people. Floodwaters cut access to at least 48 communities in Haiti and destroyed crops in three regions.

articles.title: The Chipiona Field Blooms for All Saints Between Water and Adversity
articles.author: Diario De Cádiz
articles.summary: The farmers of Chipiona recover from the floods of the spring and are preparing with optimism the campaign of All Saints. The Association of Farmers of the Northwest Coast hopes that soon the farmers will be able to support the All Saints' campaign for farmers' rights.

articles.title: Emission decisions ‘will affect sea levels for centuries' say scientists
articles.author: Alexandra Wood
articles.summary: New research shows that near-term mitigation could spare future generations around 0.6 meters of sea-level rise that would be caused by emissions between 2020 and 2090. The study was led by researchers from IIASA (International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis) and colleagues from institutions in the UK, Belgium, The Netherlands and Germany.

articles.title: Yorkshire coast climate: ‘The winners and losers' as seas off Yorkshire set to break record for highest average surface temperature since early 1980s
articles.author: Liana Jacob
articles.summary: There will be winners and losers as sea temperatures around Yorkshire hit a 40+ year high, according to marine biologist Rodney Forster. The seas off Yorkshire are set to break a record for the highest ever average surface temperature since records began four decades ago. The coldest year they recorded was in 1986 when average temperatures in the sea were 8.5C. This year the average temperatures to the end of July have been 11.4C.

articles.title: Fire levy protests on hold as council reveals how much it cost ratepayers
articles.author: Andrew Miller
articles.summary: "It's deplorable behaviour to stand out there and tell fire-prone communities that this money is not going to them," Ms Symes said. She is concerned about the impact of climate change and the increased risk of fires, floods and storms on their communities.

articles.title: Melissa strengthens into Category 4 hurricane
articles.author: Matias Delacroix
articles.summary: Melissa grew into a Category 4 hurricane on Sunday. Forecasters say it could reach Category 5 status. It's expected to reach the southern coast of Jamaica as a major hurricane late today or Tuesday morning. People on the island are urged to seek shelter immediately.

articles.title: Cyclone Montha: 269 rehabilitation centres open along the Kakinada coast
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: 269 rehabilitation centres have been opened in all government buildings, schools and cyclone relief centres along the Kakinada coast as part of preparedness for the impending cyclone Montha. At least 30 personnel from the National Disaster Response Force and 50 from the State Disaster Response force are on the ground for relief operation. In Dr. B. R. Ambedkar Konaseema district, farmers have been advised not to harvest paddy.

articles.title: Jamaicans brace for Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Paula Lindo
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is expected to make landfall on October 28 as a category three hurricane. St Thomas and Portland, two parishes on the eastern side of the island, have already begun to feel the effects of the hurricane. People are stocking up on food, water, medicine, batteries and solar-powered devices. The Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management has sent out a list of shelters.

articles.title: Work begins to repair sea wall on Peacehaven coast
articles.author: Samanta Gladkauskaite
articles.summary: Lewes District Council has begun essential maintenance on the sea wall in Peacehaven. The repairs are expected to take several weeks. The sea wall is around 50 years old and is more susceptible to the impact of winter storms. The works are being carried out by Thorne Civil Engineers and are funded by Lewes district council.

articles.title: Scientists track how foxes took over Australia in just 70 years
articles.author: Gemma Billington
articles.summary: Just 70 years after foxes were first brought to Australia, they had managed to take over most of the continent. A new study tracked how foxes spread from the continent's south-east all the way to the Pilbara in Western Australia after they were first released in Geelong in 1870. In colonial Australia, the British aristocracy wanted to have foxes to hunt. Now, foxes are the main extinction driver for most Australian species.

articles.title: CTV National News: New rules for Canadians prompt inconsistencies at U.S. border
articles.summary: There is a new rule for Canadians visiting the U.S. for more than a month. Snowbirds heading south for winter are feeling the impact of the new rule. Allison Bamford reports on the situation.   Â      .

articles.title: Cyclone ‘Montha': Odisha govt orders closure of Anganwadi Centres, beaches in multiple districts
articles.author: Mohammed Imteshal Karim
articles.summary: The Anganwadi Centres in Ganjam, Gajapati, Rayagada, Koraput, Malkangiri, Kandhamal, Kalahandi, and Nabarangpur will remain closed for two days on October 28 and 29, 2025, as a precautionary measure in view of the impending impact of Cyclone Montha. The IMD's red warning indicates a high likelihood of intense rainfall, localised flooding, and strong winds in the southern belt, particularly along coastal and hilly districts. Ganjam district administration has also announced the closure of all schools for 2 days.

articles.title: ‘Time is running out': 98 per cent of Australians all agree on one thing about the Great Barrier Reef
articles.author: Alex Blair
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef Foundation warns that the reef's survival is not assured without major investment and climate action. The reef contributes $9 billion annually to Australia's economy and supports around 77,000 full-time jobs. 98 per cent of Australians believe losing the reef would be a national tragedy, while 78 per cent say protecting the reef for future generations is important.

articles.title: The north shore picnic spot hot enough to cause skin burns
articles.author: Sydney Morning Herald
articles.summary: Urban heat is becoming a problem for all councils. Plastic grass is the hottest of all materials and is becoming the most common material for councils to deal with this problem.   Â. Â   y.  y .  y   .

articles.title: Thank you for emitting
articles.author: Bill Ponton
articles.summary: There is an endless list of personal concerns that confront individuals, such as relationships, career, children, health, etc. However, for many people there remains enough bandwidth to concern themselves with problems beyond their immediate sphere. For many in educated, credentialed class, impending Climate Armageddon from man-made CO2 is an overriding concern. In the 19th century, geologists discovered that glaciers existed on a large portion of North America and Northern Europe at repeated intervals in the recent geological past. Milutin Milankovitch, a Serbian scientist, with a lot of time on his hands while interned as a POW during World War I, discovered that the periodicity of glacial growth

articles.title: WATCH: #EyeOnMelissa: St Ann fisherfolk, vendors spend Sunday at riverside ahead of Melissa
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is on its way to Jamaica. Fishermen and craft vendors are preparing for the storm. They are worried about the potential impact of the hurricane on their livelihoods. Meteorologists warn that Melissa could bring catastrophic flooding and landslides to the country.

articles.title: Heavy rain and rising floods hit central region of Vietnam
articles.author: Vietnamnet News
articles.summary: Torrential rain and rising floods are affecting the central region, particularly Hue and Da Nang cities. River levels continue to surge.    in the National Centre for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting. It's raining heavily in Hue and Dang.

articles.title: Queensland on the brink of breaking 21-year heat records as scorching October grips the state
articles.author: Conor Breslin
articles.summary: Queensland is on track for its hottest October day in 21 years. Sydney is forecast to reach 26 degrees with a shower or two cooling the mood for the day. Melbourne is shivering through just 14 degrees and showers reminding everyone winter is not done. Adelaide is also enduring a burst of cold air behind the front as it reaches 21 degrees. Perth warms up with 32 degrees on Monday and on Tuesday it brings a sunny and cool summer vibe. Darwin remains hot and sticky with 35 degrees.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa threatens catastrophic flooding in Jamaica and Haiti
articles.summary: Melissa has grown into a Category 4 hurricane. Forecasters say it could reach Category 5 status. It's threatening to cause catastrophic flooding in the northern Caribbean, including Haiti and Jamaica, and U.S. forecasters warn it could bring torrential rain.

articles.title: WATCH: #EyeOnMelissa: Warning System triggered in St Catherine
articles.summary: The JICA Early Warning System in Old Harbour Bay, Jamaica, triggered, prompting an evacuation message around 2:43 pm Sunday. The activation was prompted by rising sea levels caused by Hurricane Melissa. The JICA system was handed over to the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management in 2024.

articles.title: Melissa strengthens into a Category 4 hurricane, threatening catastrophic flooding in Jamaica, Haiti
articles.summary: Melissa has grown into a Category 4 hurricane. Forecasters say it could reach Category 5 status. It's threatening to cause catastrophic flooding in the northern Caribbean, including Haiti and Jamaica, and U.S. forecasters warn it could bring torrential rain.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa Threatens Caribbean, 1.6M Kids at Risk
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Melissa is a Category 4 hurricane moving slowly across the Caribbean Sea. It is forecast to strengthen to Category 5. The storm is expected to bring heavy rains and heavy winds. There are fears that infrastructure could be overwhelmed and essential services disrupted. UN agencies and partners have pre-positioned lifesaving supplies to support vulnerable families.

articles.title: Mixed outlook for year ahead
articles.author: McPherson Media Group
articles.summary: Sentiment in Australia's agricultural sector softened over the winter months due to higher input costs and mixed seasonal conditions, according to the latest Rabobank Rural Confidence Survey. The survey was conducted over the last three months.      .

articles.title: Mixed outlook for year ahead
articles.author: McPherson Media Group
articles.summary: Rabobank Rural Confidence Survey finds farmers are more positive about seasonal conditions and commodity prices. Victoria and South Australia are more concerned about the weather.    .   ,   - Rabobank rural confidence survey, 2016, (http://www.rabobank.com/ruralconfidence/

articles.title: Southern Ocean Is Building a 'Burp' That Could Reignite Global Warming
articles.author: Jess Cockerill
articles.summary: The Southern Ocean has been absorbing a century's worth of CO2 and heat released by human activities. When humans stop releasing greenhouse gases into the air, the Southern Ocean will let out an abrupt 'burp' of heat that will bring on global warming for at least a century. The warming will be greatest in the Southern Hemisphere.

articles.title: A daughter of the sea
articles.summary: Khairiyah Ramanyah, 23, is one of Thailand's most recognisable young environmental activists. She is featured in Unicef Thailand's #CountMeIn 2025 campaign, which highlights youth-led climate action and calls for stronger support for young people on the front lines.

articles.title: Sino-African partnership can enhance global green development
articles.author: China Daily
articles.summary: Climate change threatens to reverse decades of progress across the Global South. Africa contributes less than 4 percent of global emissions, yet it bears a disproportionate burden of the crisis, according to UNFCCC.       .   "Climate change is the single greatest development challenge of our time"

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa's Wind Speeds Doubled in Less Than a Day
articles.author: Pioneer Press
articles.summary: Melissa grew from a tropical storm to a Category 4 hurricane this weekend. It is the fourth hurricane of this year's Atlantic hurricane season to undergo rapid intensification. The intensity of a hurricane is determined by its speed of development and its location in the Atlantic Ocean.

articles.title: Great Barrier Reef Worth $95B, Supports 77K Jobs
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef Foundation has released a report on the economic contribution of the World Heritage listed property to the national economy. It is estimated to be worth $95 billion and supports 77,000 full-time equivalent jobs. The Albanese Government is investing a record $1.2 billion over nine years to 2030 to protect and restore the reef.

articles.title: #EyeOnMelissa: Agriculture Ministry activates emergency protocols
articles.summary: The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Mining has activated its emergency protocols and convened its disaster management and mitigation committee in preparation for Hurricane Melissa. The ministry has been working with crop farmers to harvest what they can to minimise losses and with livestock farmers to ensure that they have sufficient feed and clean water for their animals. Sugar Company of Jamaica (SCJ) Holdings Limited has been directed to clean agro parks.

articles.title: Global warming reshapes extreme rainfall, snowfall across Northern Hemisphere: study
articles.summary: A recent study shed new light on how global warming has reshaped extreme rainfall and snowfall across the Northern Hemisphere over the past seven decades. The study was led by researchers from the Xinjiang Institute of Ecology and Geography of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. It suggests that warmer temperatures will mainly contribute to an increase in extreme rainfall but will have relatively modest effects on extreme snowfall.

articles.title: Cyclone Montha poses major threat to paddy crop in Coastal Andhra Pradesh
articles.author: Y Brahmaji
articles.summary: Cyclone Montha is moving closer to Andhra Pradesh. It is expected to make landfall between Bapatla and Kakinada. The storm is threatening to destroy standing crops, especially paddy, across eleven coastal districts. Nearly 20 lakh acres of paddy currently in the harvesting stage are at risk if the cyclone hits.

articles.title: #EyeonMelissa: Hurricane Melissa continuing west but still expected to turn
articles.author: Jamaica Observer
articles.summary: A hurricane warning remains in effect for Jamaica. Hurricane Melissa is moving over the Caribbean Sea south of the island. At 7:00 pm, the centre of Hurricane Melissa was located 185 km south-southwest of Kingston, or 156 km south of that place.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa poised to slam Caribbean; 1.6 million children at risk (UNOG - United Nations Office at Geneva)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: At least 1.6 million children are at risk because of Hurricane Melissa. Families in Jamaica, Haiti and surrounding islands are bracing for flooding, landslides and widespread disruption. Melissa is currently a Category 4 storm and moving slowly across the Caribbean. It is expected to bring heavy rains and hurricane-force winds.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa poised to slam Caribbean; 1.6 million children at risk
articles.author: United Nations
articles.summary: Melissa is threatening to unleash torrential rains and hurricane-force winds across the Caribbean. Families in Jamaica, Haiti and surrounding islands are bracing for flooding, landslides and widespread disruption. At least 1.6 million children are at risk as a result of the storm.

articles.title: The tough life of migratory birds is getting tougher
articles.summary: It is common for animal species to migrate but bird migration is a fascinating phenomenon both for its sheer scale and the amazing distances they cover. Since 1964, 164 bird species, many of them migratory, have gone extinct. Bird migration is necessary not only for the survival of the species but also for its survival and for its development.

articles.title: Unseasonal rains lash Guj, 8 fishermen rescued
articles.summary: Unseasonal rains hit several parts of Gujarat on Sunday, affecting farmers and coastal areas. IMD has forecast heavy to very heavy rainfall across Saurashtra and South Gujarat for the next four days. A red alert has been issued in eight districts, including Junagadh, Amreli, Gir Somnath, Surat, Tapi, Dangs, Navsari, and Valsad. The highest rainfall was reported in Sutrapada (1.5 inches), followed by Kwant, 1.42 inches, Chhota Udepur, Sankheda, and Kodinar. The rough sea conditions sank a fishing boat, named Suraj Sahakani, from

articles.title: A coastal low could bring drought relief, keep cool pattern coming into November
articles.author: Times Union
articles.summary: As drought conditions worsen, a coastal low may bring some relief and more cool weather through the start of November, according to the forecasters. The coastal low is expected to arrive at the end of October or early November and bring relief to drought-stricken areas.

articles.title: As global warming worsens, so may space communications
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Rising CO2 levels in the atmosphere could disrupt shortwave radio communications, including systems used for air traffic control, maritime communication, and radio broadcasting, according to Kyushu University researchers. CO2 also decreases the air density in the ionosphere and accelerates wind circulation.

articles.title: At least 1.6 million children at risk as Hurricane Melissa moves through the Caribbean (Canadian UNICEF Committee)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is moving slowly across the Caribbean Sea. UNICEF estimates that at least 1.6 million children are at risk. Caribbean countries, including Jamaica, Haiti, Cuba and Panama are affected by the storm.       ( Publication date: 25/10/27/25 and 26/26/25.

articles.title: Global warming shrinks male sea turtle numbers in T�rkiye
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Global warming is affecting the sex ratio of endangered caretta caretta sea turtles, with nearly 90% of hatchlings emerging as females, according to professor Yakup Kaska, director of the Center for Biological Diversity.       .   in

articles.title: Scientists just found a surprising twist in Earth's extinction story
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Extinction rates are not spiraling upward as many believe, according to a large-scale study analyzing 500 years of data. Researchers studied 500 years' worth of data on extinction rates from the past 500 years and found no increase in extinction rates.

articles.title: Mandeville residents flock bakery to stock up on bread
articles.author: Jamaica Star
articles.summary: As Hurricane Melissa nears Jamaica, bread is a hot commodity in Mandeville, Manchester. "Bread is a very important part of any household. If light goes out or gas goes out, you can purchase bread. It's been a part of civilisation for so long"

articles.title: Ten Years On, New Data Shows Fossil Fuel Expansion Is Torching the Paris Agreement
articles.author: Eli Moskowitz
articles.summary: The Paris Peace Forum is marking a decade since the landmark climate accord to limit global warming to 1.5°C. New and planned fossil fuel extraction projects would consume 11 times the remaining carbon budget compatible with keeping the temperature to 1°C and the biggest hotspots are in China, Russia, the United States, Australia, India and Saudi Arabia. The five companies linked to the largest number of new projects are TotalEnergies, CNOOC, Eni, BP, and Shell.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa strengthens in the Caribbean
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa is growing into a category four storm. It is threatening to cause potential catastrophic impacts in Jamaica. It's expected to make landfall in Jamaica within a week.      Â   - Maria.  - The National Hurricane Center.

articles.title: How climate change causes us to lose sleep
articles.author: Talker
articles.summary: People are losing an average of 15 to 17 minutes of sleep each night due to global warming. The likelihood of experiencing 'short sleep' increases by around 40% during heatwaves. The research team analysed 165 million nights of sleep data from more than 317,000 users of sleep tracking devices.
